Articles.Content:
This was basically a test to see if I could add parts to this game I discovered today.

This is a simple little booster I'm not too great at modelling but i made it in blender and the texture in GIMP.

NitroXen is a fictional company I made up a long time ago while playing gmod with friends. I kind of put this name on everything. I plan on making more parts with this blue line gray theme. Tell me if you like it!

Anyway Enjoy its similar to the solid booster but different. I find it is easy to get off the ground with it.

Screenshots:

http://i.imgur.com/fYNs3.jpg

warning large image

Download:

http://www./?1rvzgbggtqkfawz
In what way is it different? More fuel, more thrust? Less?

I like the tapered model, a nice and unique idea!

I also recommend smoothshading your model, it just makes it look a little bit nicer.
This makes my game being stuck in Loading

I like the tapered model, a nice and unique idea!

I also recommend smoothshading your model, it just makes it look a little bit nicer.

Hello, I am a friend of Xen's, and we've been working together on getting models in game. I have a similar problem to his, in that the model seems to lost all smoothing group data. I work with 3DS max, so I'm not sure if the exporter supports this.

He uses Blender (which I do NOT like, by the way), so I was wondering if you could tell us exatly what you mean? We're a bit new to this, so be kind please

To smoothshade, atleast in my program, you select all the vertices on the model, and hit 'Weld Together.'

I'm not quite sure how to do this in Blender but this might help. Keep up the good work on these models!

Now see, that looks like what I would accomplish by setting smoothing groups in 3DS Max, but they don't seem to be preserved when exporting.

Edit: out of curiosity, what program are you using?

I use Milkshape 3D.

http://chumbalum.swissquake.ch/

Now see, that looks like what I would accomplish by setting smoothing groups in 3DS Max, but they don't seem to be preserved when exporting.

Edit: out of curiosity, what program are you using?

I use Max, and it definitely preserves smoothing groups when exporting. I had more success with the Collada format than .obj, so maybe you could try that if you're not already using it.
Out of curiosity, which version of Max? Because whenever I export with Collada, the smoothing groups are _never_ preserved.

Out of curiosity, which version of Max? Because whenever I export with Collada, the smoothing groups are _never_ preserved.

2010.

Using blender hit 'Set smooth' and then export via collada .dae

I also use Blender, and it seems to preserve smoothing data.
So once again, what's the point of this? Just a different engine? Efficient at low altitude, high altitude, what?
i didnt knew we could make parts in blender ;D
too bad it will never be done
Well, that was a random necro..
Necro! Back to the dead with you!

too bad it will never be done

This thread is TWO YEARS OLD, man.
Some dead things should stay dead. I can understand comicbstudeo's desire to have MOAR PARTZ... but there are lots of part packs out there.
Closing, this has been inactive for two years and there are no signs of activity by the author on the forum.
